G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the matter concerns a residential tenancy within the City of Boston.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.201.proposition: The Boston Housing Code (105 C.M.R. § 410.201) requires that every dwelling be capable of maintaining a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 A.M. and 11:00 P.M. and 64°F at all other hours.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the rented premises.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from serious interferences with the tenancy not attributable to the tenant’s own acts. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court explains the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” in Massachusetts landlord-tenant law and explicitly ties it to freedom from substantial interference with the tenancy, not limited to intentional acts. In discussing the common-law covenant incorporated into G.L. c. 186, § 14, the opinion cites earlier cases and defines quiet enjoyment as protection against serious impairments to the character and value of the premises, which supports the stated proposition that the covenant protects tenants from serious interferences not attributable to their own acts.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: The repeated failure to maintain adequate heat constitutes a material and substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with constructive eviction and breach of quiet enjoyment caused by excessive noise from a bar, not by failure to maintain adequate heat. While the court cites earlier cases, including ones involving heat and other services, as examples of conditions that can breach quiet enjoyment, Blackett itself does not address or hold that repeated failure to maintain adequate heat is a material and substantial interference. Using Blackett as direct authority for that specific heating-related proposition is therefore inaccurate, though it is consistent with its general reasoning about substantial interferences with habitability.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services)."

*Al\u2013Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a landlord’s failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code or to maintain habitable conditions constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Al–Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Darmetko v. Boston Housing Authority*, 378 Mass. 758 (1979).
*Al\u2013Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly characterizes a landlord’s failure to repair known defects and to keep an apartment in habitable condition as conduct that can violate the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. In discussing prior cases, the court approvingly cites Darmetko and Dorgan as instances where failure to repair a leaky roof or to bring and keep an apartment in habitable condition breached quiet enjoyment, thereby recognizing that violations of the State Sanitary Code/habitability duties can constitute such a breach. Although the specific issue in Al–Ziab concerns lead paint and the need to show at least negligence, its reasoning affirms the underlying proposition about habitability-related violations supporting § 14 liability.
*Al\u2013Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

*Darmetko v. Boston Housing Authority*,.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a landlord’s failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code or to maintain habitable conditions constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Al–Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Darmetko v. Boston Housing Authority*, 378 Mass. 758 (1979).
*Darmetko v. Boston Housing Authority*,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats the landlord’s failure to repair serious defects (a leaky roof) as both a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and as an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The SJC accepts the Housing Court’s conclusion that the unrepaired leaks interfered with quiet enjoyment and then explains that § 14’s damages are measured by the tenant’s actual (habitability-based) losses, thereby recognizing that habitability-type code violations can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The case thus supports using sanitary-code / habitability failures as the basis for a quiet-enjoyment claim and statutory damages.
*Darmetko v. Boston Housing Authority*,.relevant_excerpt: “The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. We see no reason, however, for the plaintiff to recover cumulatively for a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and for interference with her quiet enjoyment of the premises.… Section 14 of G. L. c. 186 expands the measure of damages to include all ‘actual and consequential damages’ where, as here, there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: The landlord’s obligation to maintain heating systems in good repair is also imposed by G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and by 105 C.M.R. §§ 410.190–410.201.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7\u00a7 410.190\u2013410.proposition: The landlord’s obligation to maintain heating systems in good repair is also imposed by G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and by 105 C.M.R. §§ 410.190–410.201.

*Heman v. O\u2019Shea*, 20 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s response to Plaintiff’s complaints was unreasonable and ineffective, amounting to neglect and indifference rather than prompt rectification as required by law. See *Heman v. O’Shea*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 911 (1985).
*Heman v. O\u2019Shea*, 20 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns probate jurisdiction, validity and enforceability of a purchase and sale agreement, the effect of a license to sell, and proper consolidation of related actions. It does not discuss a defendant’s response to complaints, standards of reasonableness or effectiveness of remedial action, neglect, indifference, or any duty of “prompt rectification.” The proposition attributed to Heman v. O’Shea is therefore unrelated to the issues actually decided and is not supported by this case.
*Heman v. O\u2019Shea*, 20 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: In the background at the consolidated hearing on the petition for license to sell and the complaint for declaratory relief was evidence of an oral offer higher than Murray’s. That offer bore on Livia’s obligations only insofar as she was tied to an agreement conditioned upon Shirley’s obtaining a license to sell. We explicated the position of a licensee who receives a bona fide higher offer on equally advantageous terms (in the instant case all cash) in Onanian v. Leggat, 2 Mass. App. Ct. at 629-631. Should the administratrix receive a higher offer, she may bring that to the attention of the Probate Court by a motion to amend the license granted.

*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.proposition: Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment was further impaired by the resulting health problems and financial hardship caused by Defendant’s conduct. See *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses serious interference with quiet enjoyment caused by pervasive criminal activity and the landlord’s failure to act, but it does not link that interference to tenants’ health problems or financial hardship as elements of the quiet enjoyment claim. The court frames the impairment in terms of loss of use of common areas and substantial interference with tenancy, not resulting health or financial consequences. Thus, the case does not support the specific proposition that quiet enjoyment was “further impaired by the resulting health problems and financial hardship.”
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions were willful or, at a minimum, knowing, given that Plaintiff repeatedly notified him of the heating failure and he failed to take adequate corrective measures. See *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not address whether a landlord’s acts or omissions are willful or knowing based on repeated notice of a heating failure or failure to take corrective measures. The only discussion of willfulness concerns rent control overcharges, where the court affirms the trial judge’s finding that the landlord’s violation was not willful. The case therefore does not support the claimed proposition about willful or knowing failure to remedy heating problems after notice.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s finding that Young’s violation was not wilful is not clearly erroneous, as Young could easily have had the property decontrolled much earlier. The tenant is, however, entitled to attorney’s fees and costs under the ordinance, as § 9 expressly provides for liability for reasonable attorney’s fees and costs for any person who ‘receives, or retains any payment of rent, in excess of the maximum lawful rent.’ A showing that a violation is neither wilful nor the result of failure to take practicable precautions merely limits the amount of liquidated damages to the amount of the overcharge.”

*Yoshinobu v. Providence & Worcester R.R.raw_text: *Yoshinobu v. Providence & Worcester R.R.*, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 908 (1983)
*Yoshinobu v. Providence & Worcester R.R.proposition: 8. *Yoshinobu v. Providence & Worcester R.R.*, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 908 (1983)
*Yoshinobu v. Providence & Worcester R.R.case_name: Quincy Mutual Fire Insurance v. Abernathy
*Yoshinobu v. Providence & Worcester R.R.support_reasoning: The prompt lists only “8. Yoshinobu v. Providence & Worcester R.R.” as the proposition, without describing the underlying legal principle, while the opinion text provided is actually from an insurance coverage case (an unnamed insurer v. Abernathy/Hannon) dealing with an intentional‑injury exclusion in a homeowner’s policy. The text does not mention Yoshinobu or Providence & Worcester Railroad, nor does it concern railroad liability; therefore, it cannot be assessed as supporting that separate proposition and appears mismatched to the cited case name.
*Yoshinobu v. Providence & Worcester R.R.relevant_excerpt: “The policy excludes from coverage ‘bodily injury which is either expected or intended from the standpoint of the insured.’ … Only those injuries foreseen or intended by the insured are excluded from coverage. … It was substantially certain that James’ act would result in injuries to the occupants of the car. … The plaintiff insurer was entitled to judgment, declaring that the Abernathys’ injuries fall within the policy’s exclusion clause, as a matter of law.”

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The user’s proposition is only a bare citation to Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas with no described legal principle, so it is impossible to compare a specific claimed rule against the opinion’s actual holdings. The case clearly addresses several issues—damages for breach of implied warranty of habitability in subsidized housing, the standard for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and c. 93A liability and multiple damages—but without knowing which of these (or something else) proposition 9 refers to, I cannot reliably say it supports the unspecified proposition.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: “On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown. On remand, Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on this basis. … We agree with Thomas that the judge erred in failing to find a violation of G. L. c. 93A, §§ 2 (a) and 9, based on the substantial and material breach of the implied warranty of habitability caused by the condition of the premises leased to her.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: The user’s “proposition” is simply the case citation itself, without any stated legal principle, so there is no concrete proposition to compare against the opinion. The excerpt is a concurring/dissenting opinion that discusses implied warranty and code-based duties, but without knowing what legal rule proposition 10 is supposed to assert, I cannot reliably say the case supports it. Accordingly, I must treat it as not shown to support the unspecified proposition.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code. That holding is sufficient to dispose of the only issues raised in these cases, and to that extent I concur with the opinion.”
